title: What are the methods of philosophy that lead to wisdom and truth? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well structured and logic thinking when in depth - has always been a way to search out truth in regard to the human being and what surrounds us. Therefor is philosophy the mother of science - and science as we know it today came in fact from philosophy and the epistemology within it, and the metaphysics. Does this lead to wisdom and truth? NO - truth is the Lord in regard to all existences in the Universe. These are facts in life that you will find if and when you truly search - with an open mind - for the Truth. Is then structured and logic thinking in depth - wisdom? Is the thought based “wisdom” from the hindus or buddists philosophies - wisdom? Or even truth? Now, to be able and capable of judgements within this field you need to understand these matters first. You need to understand who God is in fact. And who God is not. What then comes from God - and what does in fact NOT come from God. Wisdom is considered (on the basis of the thoughts of Aristotle) to be a mixture of the theoretical knowledge (sophia) and the practical (phronesis) …(Kant made the same distinction and deepened the thoughts in regard). And where the human being has integrated these parts into one solid ground/foundation within him/her self. So wisdom would then stand for: a capacity to have a sound judgment and conduct and at the same time a deep understanding of theoretical knowledge of the highest kind. But… real deep wisdom is something quite different in fact - even if and when a person has acquired the latter in the above mentioned manner- and (also) it is the “fear of God”. NOW, fear does not really mean the lexical definition of the word - but to be able and capable to understand the role we - being humans- have, and the Role of God in all that exists. Thereby act and think, accordingly. In all matters.

By definition, philo sophia is the love of wisdom. The prescribed method of doing this is to first study mathematics to learn logic, then to study the natural sciences to learn the laws of nature before studying philosophy. This is the path that took. I finished am stars in engineering before starting to study philosophy. Armed with logic, reason and the natural laws you are ready to start questioning, and uncovering rhetoric with the Socratic method. Pealing back the illogical rhetoric is what reveals wisdom. The first this I questioned as a philopsher was the current two-factor model for human behavior and disease. From a pure mathematical viewpoint, the statistics from all the identical twin studies ever done are not represented by two independent factor, but five are required to represent the statistics! The results are published in my paper entitled: Behavior Model Definition With this investigation, I discovered a particular behavior of modern science and the desperate need for philosophy. That is, when science is confronted with a result that they cannot explain, they often ignore the data. In my project Torn Between Two Worlds, I discuss other areas where science is failing because they are not willing to question and discover the wisdom that could result. The founders of science were also philosophers and the wisdom shines through today with theories that survived 2,500+ years. To put it dramatically, once can imagine a scholar of the young School of Athens paying a holiday visit to Abdera (with due caution to keep it secret from his Master), and on being received by the wise, far-travelled and world-famous old gentleman Democritus, asking him questions on the atoms, the shape of the earth, on moral conduct, God and the immortality of the soul – without being repudiated on any of these points. Where can we find absolute TRUTH or "true knowledge"? Certainly not from mankind's flawed philosophies which change like the wind. Knowledge is knowing about something, but wisdom is understanding how that knowledge should be applied or used. It is safe to say that there is more knowledge in the world today than there has ever been. In fact, we are told that knowledge is increasing so rapidly that it doubles every other year. In spite of this fact, our world today is also marked by meaninglessness. There has never been a time in the history of the world when so many people were searching for purpose and meaning in their lives. How do you explain the above? Is it not explained by the fact that our world today is drowning in ever-increasing knowledge at the same time it is experiencing an ever-worsening draught of wisdom? Knowledge is outracing wisdom in our modern-day world. Consequently, men are coming to know more and more about less and less, while understanding less and less about more and more. While knowledge/truth may explain how brown cows eat green grass and give white milk that is turned into yellow butter, only wisdom can enlighten us to the meaning of life. Holy Scripture [EXCERPT] Now, there is a wisdom of this world, which should not be confused with the wisdom of God (1 Corinthians 1:18-25). “The wisdom of this world is foolishness to God. It never leads men to God nor to true wisdom, which alone reveals to us the true meaning of life. Instead, it only leads men to destruction; as King Solomon warned, “There is a way which seems right to a man, but the end thereof are the ways of death” (Proverbs 14:12; 16:25). To the wisdom of this world, the preaching of the cross is foolishness. But to the wisdom that comes only from God, the preaching of the cross (Jesus’ payment for everyone’s sins) which is the central message of the “Holy Scriptures,” is the only thing that makes men “wise unto salvation” (2 Timothy 3:15). [EXCERPT]

The word philosophy itself means love of knowledge. Epistemology is the branch of philosophy that deals with the limits of all human knowledge. From the greek: Episteme(knowledge) logos (word/speech. Surely this can be claimed as one possible road to wisdom. However, the study of any of the branches of philosophy, and I suspect, many other disciplines can also lead to wisdom. I say this because I believe, as many others do that wisdom and knowledge are not interchangeable. One can acquire a great deal of knowledge and still completely lack wisdom. ( I probably fall somewhere along that line). Wisdom is how you use knowledge judiciously to better oneself, another, or the environment, or all three. Usually a difficult task, which is why wisdom is prized. Despite having a great deal of knowledge to bring to bear on any given problem, still, even very knowledgeable people fail the task. Truth is a subject also dealt with by epistemology or at least ultimate truth is,(Thanks Prof. French!) That truth being always the same regardless of context. Logic also touches on truth although truth more subjective or of varying degrees in one way or another. Here, I will bow to the special knowledge of those who study philosophy. I may be already out of my depth. I am still only a padawan. I answer only to keep philosophy fresh in my head. I hope you can use the info.

Understanding opposite ideas, in my opinion. Each is the hero and center of their own drama and the universe. But at the same time we figure in other dramas. - Which points to a fact that each is unique because the nodes of associations, circumstances, experiences, typologies and so on, is different. - Each entity and idea appears to be a “janus faced” having opposite spins of the same abstract. - So to choose one philosophy over another, in my opinion, is a matter of choice and what is relative. But when we try to impose the philosophy upon others, whether it is a ‘political ideology,’ ‘religious fanaticism,’ or ‘selfish bully,’ etc, then there is something wrong with applying that philosophy at other’s expense. - For example, whether it is religion, politics, economic systems, if one brand thinks it is the head and the other an a$$ and proclaims it has no need of them, then how is the body truly a love of wisdom? - Or what if one proclaims, “My God is better than your God,” and “I’ll show YOU whose God is GOD!” then where is the “love of wisdom”? - If we consider that philosophy, used as a methodology, there are certain fundamental questions. One is “What is the nature of God?” - From that perspective, we must define what is God. If “God” is “The Supreme Being,” then there is one God. If “God” is “a Supreme Being” then there are many “Gods.” - That means that if human beings agree that “God is The Supreme Being,” than our methodology can differentiate between the “Concept of God” being “One God,” and the differences in religion that all have sacred teachings and dogmas, are acknowledging the same God. Whereas if the concept of “God,” is “A supreme being,” then the religions have an inherent problem because they are teaching ways to turn people against each other. - So, the question comes in, “What is the methodology for philosophy” that would lead to the truth about the Nature of God and the human beings so that they likewise become “One with the Holy Invisible Spirit,” versus “How can the philosophy divide humans by having more than one Supreme being?” This is my opinion, but I am sure others have more.

response.answer_text: To appreciate philosophy one must first appreciate rhetoric. The second appreciation must concern ideology. Ideology and rhetoric are the terrible twins of language and politics. They seduce with their simplistic ‘truths’ and inveigle themselves into our very sense of identity. We become the message. And in so doing we validate those who would hold sway over us. Read history for proof of this, especially the 20th century. And then study the present. Philosophers question everything. And in their application of the method first devised by Socrates, they unceasingly search for the truths which inform the human condition, and its potential. No ideology or rhetoric can survive the simple question ‘why?’ We must be rigorous in asking this question of everything, especially of those who would present us with their utopia, their truth, their ‘final solutions’. Philosophers are the sworn enemy of demagogues, stupidity, lazy thinking, assumptions, beliefs, and ignorance. Philosophy is high-level thinking; the reserve of those with the intellectual tools, mental agility, and strength of mind to critically question what you might take as given but is, in fact, merely your illusion.

Living life while questioning and examining our perspective on that life can bring us to a certain philosophy, maybe truth, and perhaps wisdom, which is basically an attitude of patience that one has acquired from experience. What is the context for the wisdom you seek? How to better relate to your fellow human beings? If so, just continue to observe, observe and observe some more until you clearly see what is what in this world, in yourself, in others. Hopefully that vision will help you to feel for yourself what it is that we are so when others irritate and annoy, you no longer react with the same irritability because you know from your own experience that they are just like you and you are just like them, survivors, scavengers and opportunists. And that is as it should be, why should things be otherwise?

I can’t tell you about wisdom, but I can tell you about truth: Check what you believe. Why do I believe guns are good/bad? Why do I believe free markets are good/bad? Why do I believe abortion is acceptable/evil? It goes beyond politics. Ask yourself even more fundamental questions: Why do I think this food is healthy and that food is unhealthy? Why do I think it’s important to get married and have kids? Why do I think it’s important to get a job? Why do I think it’s important not to break the law? As you question yourself more and more, you’ll realize that much of what you think you know is really sort of arbitrary. Eventually you’ll ask yourself, what do I actually know for real? And you’ll start building up your own philosophy of life — what’s good, what’s true, what’s honorable, what’s real, etc. — from the ground up.

As you can see by the answers this far, whether and to what extent philosophy generates wisdom and/or truth depends on one’s conception of the nature of philosophy itself. I incline to the view that philosophy is at its best when it is clarifies our concepts, and thereby our thoughts, and can lead to the wisdom that follows from a more refined (in the sense of sharpened) way of understanding the world. Philosophy construed this way aims at impeccably clear forms of thought and argument, and by doing so can generate philosophical insights, which can be of value for better understanding our human reality.

“wisdom” and “truth” is a faith-based belief system, where you artificially create a need and fill it using words augmented by gestures — all relying on some authority other than nature itself. there is no ‘thought’, just ‘thinking’ philosophy is thinking itself and used to shred beliefs and opinions. philosophy has no content and therefore has nothing in it needed anything more than perfection of technique. ‘wisdom’ is a dumpster of used ideas. ‘truth’ is a day pass on the bus of life.

Methods of philosophy alone will not lead one to wisdom or truth because many of those who seek and attain the title of philosopher are simply idiots. One must first acquire as much experience of life as possible before turning to philosophy so that one learns to recognize those who speak truthfully and those who dissemble. An honest philosopher does not know everything and readily admits this, but the things he does know and shares are the seeds from which wisdom grows.

Some philosophers might say that true wisdom is found when one learns that there is no truth. Whether or not they are right, it is important to know that one of the first things you should know about philosophy is that you need to figure out how to stop thinking in terms of truth and falsehood. Wisdom is the goal, not truth. It seems wrong, but that is because you are thinking in terms of right and wrong, not philosophically (where the existence of right and wrong are disputed). Sadly, nothing will ever irrefutably lead you to truth, and philosophy is all about refuted beliefs.

I believe we find our own truths (which will eventually correlate with a larger truth). Thus the method to acquire this is unique to each consciousness. We all start, and end at the same place in this mortal life - so don’t worry about it, but you can definitely find truth and wisdom during the walk, from beginning to end…
